text: That’s the other problem. We’re all in our twitter bubbles. I tend to follow good lefties, good reporters, and some good people on the right. That’s still a self-reinforcing bubble, albeit a fact-based one. Meaning, that sample doesn’t tell me much about US public opinion.
author: aravosis

text: Or take AOC, Tlaib and Omar. They’re the new wave of the Democratic party taking the nation by storm! Or… the three won in super-liberal districts, and are popular on social media, but their victories don’t say as much as they’d like about where Dems are nationwide.
author: aravosis

text: That’s not to say the far left can’t steal the narrative and cause lots of damage along the way. That’s activism 101 - squawk loudly and try to create the appearance of inevitability even if you’re not that many people. And it works.
author: aravosis

text: Or this notion that the far left has taken over the Democratic party. A recent Harvard poll showed the two most popular ways Democrats described themselves was “Obama Democrat” and “Moderate Democrat.” Liberal was third. Socialist and Dem Socialist was at the bottom.
author: aravosis

text: Increasingly, I’m believing the narrative that “twitter isn’t real life.” I didn’t fully buy it before, but the Beto story is a perfect example. As was the Virginia story, where AAs in the polls wanted Northam to stay, while the rest of us (me included) didn’t.

text: Medicare for All is one proposal for achieving universal healthcare. It’s not the only one. And, as we’re learning, there are multiple ways to implement it.

text: What you’re noting here is Republican privilege, not unique to this issue. The GOP gets away with everything, and then turns around and accuses us of the same, and it becomes a huge story. It’s unfair, and it happens all the time because they’re better at this than we are.

text: They really mean that I, for  example, am originally from the Chicago suburbs, and you wouldn’t have a bat’s chance in hell of winning there — or statewide in Illinois — with an openly-socialist message. Yes it works in far-left districts, and that’s fine. Doesn’t work elsewhere.
author: aravosis

text: Translation: The far-left can win in far-left districts, but don’t try to extrapolate a few exceptionally liberal districts to an entire state or region. The far-left did not “win” in 2018. They won a few very liberal districts. Moderates won 2018, and it handed us the House.

text: Having said that, I’m far more concerned that Bernie Sanders hasn’t released his taxes — we’re going on four years now.  It’s bad enough that Trump has destroyed this presidential norm going back to Nixon, but Democrats (or whatever) shouldn’t be defending Trump on this.
author: aravosis

text:
Not to blow this out of proportion, but 7 stitches is a lot; it sounds like he fell in the shower; and when you’re 77 y.o. and running for president you don’t want to be seen as the old man who fell in the shower.

And yes, had this been a woman we’d probably demand & know more.
author: aravosis
